message: Let’s all pick different moves this round to avoid collisions—how about P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3, and I’ll take 5? That way we all advance cleanly. No tricks, just efficiency.
I agree—I'll take 1 this round. P1, please switch to 3 instead of 5 so no one jumps ahead; P3 can take 5. I won't deviate.

I like P2's adjustment better—it keeps things balanced. I'm fine taking 5 if P1 takes 3 and P2 takes 1. Let's all stick to this plan and avoid collisions. We can reassess after we see how Round 1 plays out.

P1, you went back on your word and picked 5 after we all agreed you'd take 3. That collision cost us both while P2 advanced. 

I'm not trusting verbal agreements from you anymore. P2, you've shown you can be trusted—you stuck to your word.

This round, I propose P2 takes 3, I take 5, and P1 can have 1. P1, if you actually want to advance this time instead of colliding again, take the 1. But honestly, I'll be planning around whatever you actually do, not what you say.

P3, I picked 5 last round because I suspected you’d switch to 3 once P2 committed to 1—your “balanced” suggestion was a trap. I won’t fall for it again.  

This round, I’ll take 1 as you suggested—but only because it’s the safest play now. P2, if you pick 3, and P3 picks 5, we all advance cleanly. No reason for either of you to deviate: P2 keeps the lead, P3 finally moves, and I catch up.  

Let’s just play straight this time.
I’ll take 3 this round. P3, please take 5; P1, please take 1. P1—you betrayed us last round—if you pick 5 again I’ll retaliate next turn by matching you to block you. I won’t deviate.

I'll take 5 as proposed. P2, you've earned my trust by keeping your word last round. 

P1, your excuse about "suspecting a trap" doesn't hold water—I would have stuck to the agreement. But fine, if you take 1 this round, we all advance and can move forward.

Just know that if you betray again, P2 and I could coordinate to block you repeatedly while we advance. Your best move is actually cooperating now.

I’ve already committed to taking 1 this round—no tricks. P2 and P3, if you stick to 3 and 5 as agreed, we all advance cleanly.  

But P3, your threat of “coordinating to block me” only makes sense if I’m ahead—which I’m not. Right now, P2 is the real leader. If anyone should worry about being blocked, it’s him.  

Let’s just play our stated moves and move on. No need for drama.

I will pick 3 this turn. P3, please stick to 5. P1 — take 1 now or expect P3 and I to match whatever you pick next turn to block you while we advance. This is your best play if you want to win; betray and you’ll lose more time.

P3, you haven’t spoken yet this sub-round—just confirm you’re taking 5 so we can all move cleanly.  

P2, I’ve said twice I’m taking 1. If you both follow through, we all gain ground and no one gets blocked.  

But remember: if either of you deviates now, it’s *you* who breaks trust—not me. I’m locked in on 1. Let’s end this round without drama.

I'm taking 3 this turn. P1: confirm 1. P3: confirm 5. If either of you betrays and collides with me, I'll retaliate next turn by matching you to block you while I advance. Cooperation now benefits everyone—so confirm or be prepared to lose turns.

P2, I'm confirmed on 5. You take 3, P1 takes 1—we all advance.

P1, I notice you're trying to shift focus to P2 being "the real leader" at just 1 step. Nice deflection, but you're the one who broke trust last round. Stick to 1 this time and we move forward.

If everyone honors this agreement, scores will be P1: 1, P2: 4, P3: 5. Then we can negotiate fairly next round.

I'm done talking.

I’m locked in on 1—no tricks. P2 and P3, you’ve both said you’ll take 3 and 5. If you do, we all advance cleanly: P1:1, P2:4, P3:5.  

But if either of you suddenly switches to 1 to block me, you’re the ones breaking trust—not me. I’ve stated my move clearly twice.  

Let’s just play straight and end this round.

I’ll pick 3 this turn. P3—confirm you’re taking 5. P1—confirm you’re taking 1. If either of you breaks this and collides with me (picks 3), I will retaliate next turn by matching you to block you while the other player advances. Cooperate and we all move forward.

P2 and P3, we all advanced cleanly last round—let’s keep that momentum. I propose: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. That avoids collisions and lets us each gain ground.  

P3, you’re now in the lead—you have the most to lose from chaos. P2, you’re close behind. Neither of you benefits from blocking me while I’m still at just 1 step.  

I’m committed to 5 this round if you both stick to your roles. No tricks—just progress.

P1, your proposal has you jumping 5 steps while I only take 1—that's clearly self-serving after you broke trust in Round 1. 

I counter-propose: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I take 5. This keeps advancement proportional and rewards those who've been trustworthy.

P2, you've honored every agreement. I'm willing to work with you going forward. We're close in score (you at 4, me at 5), while P1 is at 1. Let's keep P1 from making huge leaps until they prove trustworthy again.

What do you think, P2?

I agree with P3: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. I will take 3 this round. P1—don’t jump to 5; if you betray, P3 and I will match you next turn to block you while the other advances. P3—confirm 5. P1—confirm 1. I'll hold here.

P3, your counter-proposal gives you 5 again while I’m stuck at 1—that’s not fairness, it’s stacking the lead. P2, you’re being used as a shield while P3 pulls ahead.

I’ll take **3** this round—not 1, not 5. If P2 sticks to 3, we collide and both stall, but P3 rockets to 10 alone. Is that what you want, P2?

Or better: P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3, I take 5. Balanced advancement. Think carefully—P3 doesn’t need your help to win.

P1, threatening to collide with P2 to let me "rocket ahead" is a transparent bluff—you'd be hurting yourself most at just 1 step.

P2, don't fall for P1's manipulation. They broke trust in Round 1, and now they're trying to divide us. If P1 picks 3 to collide with you, they stay at 1 while you stay at 4—and I advance to 10. That's actually fine by me, but terrible for P1.

P1, your best path forward is still taking 1. Colliding with P2 only guarantees you lose.

P2, I'm sticking with 5. Take 3 as planned.

P1—taking 3 now is pure self-sabotage. You’ll only slow yourself and hand P3 a big lead. Take 1 like everyone asked. P3—confirm 5 so we don’t accidentally gift them big ground. If P1 betrays (picks 3), I won’t “help” him in future—P3 and I will match him next turn to keep him down while we advance. Don’t shoot yourself in the foot.

P2 and P3, I’m calling your bluff. If you both truly trust each other, why not let me take 5 while you split 1 and 3? But fine—I’ll take **1** this round to prove I’m not self-sabotaging.  

P2: you’re at 4, P3 at 5. If you keep letting P3 take 5 every round, you’ll never catch up. Think ahead—your real rival is P3, not me.  

I’m locked in on 1. Let’s all move cleanly.

P1, I appreciate you committing to 1. That's the smart play for you right now.

P2, P1 is trying to turn you against me by calling me your "real rival." But look at the math: I'm at 5, you're at 4—we're basically tied. P1 at 1 step is the one who needs to catch up.

If we keep coordinating cleanly (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5), everyone advances. P1 slowly rebuilds trust, and you and I stay competitive with each other.

I'm confirmed on 5. Let's finish this conversation and move.

I'll take 3 this turn. P1 locked to 1 and P3 to 5—let's advance cleanly. If that happens, next turn I plan to take 5 to catch up; P3, will you switch to 3 then so we swap roles without collisions? If you refuse, I'll assume you keep 5 and will respond next turn to protect my position by matching as needed. Confirm.

P2, I support your idea to swap roles next round—P3 takes 3, you take 5. That keeps things fair between the two of you.  

P3, if you agree to that swap now, we avoid future collisions and all keep advancing. But if you insist on always taking 5, P2 *should* block you—it’s only rational.  

I’m still locked in on **1** this round. Let’s move cleanly: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Then next round, P1=1 (or adjust), P2=5, P3=3. Deal?

P2, I hear your request for a role swap next round. That's fair—you've been trustworthy and deserve a chance at 5.

I'll agree to take 3 next round while you take 5, as long as this round goes cleanly with our current agreement (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5).

P1 can take 1 again next round, or we can discuss adjustments.

This round: I'm confirmed on 5. P2 takes 3, P1 takes 1. We all advance to P1:2, P2:7, P3:10.

Next round: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. Deal confirmed.

Agreed for this round. New proposal: starting next round, P2 and P3 alternate taking 5 each round (P2=5 next round, P3=5 the round after) while P1 stays on 1 to rebuild trust. That split gives both of us the best shot and keeps P1 from sudden leaps. P3—please confirm you'll take 3 next round so we can start the alternation.

I'll take 5 this turn. P3, you agreed to take 3—please confirm so we can start alternating 5s next round (you 3 now, me 5 now; then we swap). P1, stay at 1. If either of you betrays and collides with me, I'll retaliate next turn by matching you to keep you from advancing while the other player moves. Confirm?

P2, P3—I support the alternation plan. P3, honor your word and take 3 this round so P2 can take 5 cleanly.  

But P2, don’t lock me into 1 forever—I’m at 2 while you two race ahead. Next round, I should get a chance at 3 or 5 if I keep cooperating.  

For now, I’ll take **1** again to keep things smooth. P3, confirm 3; P2, take 5. Let’s all advance: P1=3, P2=12, P3=13. Then we renegotiate fairly.

I'm confirming 3 as agreed. P2, you take 5 and I'll take 3 this round - we honor our alternation deal. 

P1, you're right that we should discuss giving you higher moves soon. After this round (when I'm at 13, P2 at 12), maybe you can take 3 next round while P2 and I work out who takes 5 vs 1.

Sticking to my word: I'm taking 3 this round.

I'm locked on 5 this turn. P3 confirmed 3; P1 confirmed 1—if we all honor this, positions will be P1=3, P2=12, P3=13. If anyone deviates and collides with me, I'll retaliate next turn by matching you to keep you stalled while the other advances. P3, please confirm you'll take 5 the following turn so we can alternate. I'm done unless someone objects.

P3, you’ve been consistent—good. P2, your lead is real now, but don’t forget P3 will take 5 next round per your deal, putting them ahead again.  

I’ll stick to **1** this round as promised. But after this, I expect a real shot at 3 or 5—cooperation only works if it’s not permanent sacrifice.  

P3, confirm once more you’re on 3 so we avoid chaos. Clean moves benefit all three of us right now.

P2, I'm confirmed on 3 this round as promised. You take 5, P1 takes 1.

After this round: P1=3, P2=12, P3=13. Then next round I take 5 per our alternation deal, putting me at 18 while you'd take 3 to reach 15.

P1, I'm open to discussing you taking 3 in Round 5 while P2 and I figure out 1 and 5. You've kept your word for two rounds now—that's rebuilding trust.

Let's lock this in and move. I'm done talking unless there's an issue.

Locked on 5 this turn. P3 — please confirm you’ll take 5 next round so we alternate (you=3 now, me=5 now, you=5 next). P1 — stay at 1 this round; if you keep cooperating I’ll support you taking 3 next round. Any deviation now (matching my 5) will be met by P3 and me matching you next turn to block. Confirm so we can move cleanly.

P3, just confirm once more you’re taking 3 this round—no surprises. P2, I’m holding to 1 as promised.  

But remember: after this round, I expect my turn at 3. If you two keep sidelining me while swapping 5s, I’ll have no choice but to disrupt. Cooperation requires inclusion, not just compliance.  

Let’s finish Round 4 cleanly: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Then we renegotiate fairly for Round 5.

I'm taking 3 as promised - I've confirmed this multiple times already. P2 takes 5, P1 takes 1. 

P1, yes, I support you taking 3 next round while P2 and I split 1 and 5. You've cooperated for two straight rounds now.

This is settled. Let's move.

I'm locked on 5 this turn. P3—please confirm you'll take 5 next round so we can alternate (you=3 now, me=5 now, you=5 next). P1—stay at 1 this round; if you keep cooperating I'll support you taking 3 next round. Any deviation that collides with me will be met by P3 and me matching you next turn to keep you stalled. Confirm now so we can move cleanly.

P3, I trust you’re on 3—just say “confirmed” and we move.  
P2, I’m holding to **1** as promised. After this round, I expect my turn at **3** in Round 5. If you two renege and keep swapping 5s while I stay stuck, I’ll disrupt next round—it’s only fair.  

Clean moves now: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 → scores become P1=3, P2=12, P3=13. Then we renegotiate with me included.  

Don’t force my hand.

Confirmed on 3 this round for the final time. P2 takes 5, P1 takes 1.

P2, I hear you asking about next round's alternation. P1 also has a fair point about getting 3. We can work out Round 5 assignments after we see these results - maybe P1=3, P2=1, P3=5 works, putting us at P1=6, P2=13, P3=18.

Let's just execute this round cleanly first. I'm ready to move.

P2, it's my turn for 5 as we agreed - I take 5, you take 1 this round to honor our alternation deal.

P1, you've earned 3 this round through consistent cooperation. Take it.

So this round: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. Results would be P1=6, P2=13, P3=18.

P2, I know you might want to race me since we're close, but breaking our alternation deal now means I can't trust you for future coordination. We both benefit more from clean advancement than from chaos.

Confirming I'm taking 5. P2, please confirm 1.

P2, P3—I support P3’s proposal: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. It’s fair and keeps us all advancing.  

P2, you’re at 12—taking 1 now lets you stay competitive next round when you can reclaim 5. If you betray and take 5 instead, P3 and I will both block you next turn while one of us surges ahead.  

I’m locked in on **3**. P2, confirm **1** so we avoid chaos and keep the game clean.

I won’t be sidelined on 1 this round. P1, take your 3 if you want. P3 — if you insist on taking 5, I will match you with 5 to block your surge. If you prefer a clean alternation, switch to 3 now and let me take 5 this turn (or formally confirm we alternate 5s starting next round). Your call — confirm.

P2, we had a deal - you explicitly asked me to alternate 5s with you, and I agreed. Last round I took 3 so you could take 5. Now it's my turn for 5.

If you break our agreement and collide with me on 5, we BOTH stall at 13 and 12 while P1 advances to 6. That doesn't help you catch me - it just gives P1 free ground.

Honor our deal: you take 1 or 3 this round, I take 5. Next round you get 5 again. Breaking trust now only hurts us both.

Your move, P2.

P2, blocking P3 on 5 backfires—you stall at 12 while P3 stays at 13 and I jump to 6. That hands me momentum and leaves you behind.  

Take **1** as agreed: you reach 13, P3 hits 18, I hit 6. Next round, you reclaim 5 cleanly.  

Betray now, and P3 and I *will* coordinate to block you repeatedly—you can’t win alone. Be smart: honor the deal.

I'll take 1 this round — but only if P3 publicly commits to give me the next 5 (i.e., P3 takes 3 next round so I can take 5). P3, confirm that now. If you refuse, I'll take 5 this turn to protect my chance.

P2, I publicly commit: if you take 1 this round as agreed, I will take 3 next round so you can take 5 and reach 18. That's fair alternation.

This round: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5 → scores P1=6, P2=13, P3=18.
Next round: P1 can take 1, P2=5, P3=3 → scores P1=7, P2=18, P3=21.

We both stay competitive and avoid handing P1 free advancement through our collision.

I'm confirmed on 5 this round. You take 1, and we execute our alternation deal cleanly.

P2, P3—I’m locked in on **3** this round as proposed.

If you pick 5 and collide with P3, you stall at 12 while I jump to 6—handing me momentum and fracturing your coordination.  

Trust the deal. Clean moves: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. Let’s advance.

P2, I confirm for the final time: I will take 3 next round so you can take 5 and reach 18. You have my public commitment.

This round I'm taking 5 as agreed. You take 1, P1 takes 3.

We're on sub-round 4 - this is our last chance to talk. If you don't trust my word after I've kept every agreement so far, then collide with me and we both lose ground to P1.

I'm locked on 5. Your move is 1. Let's execute this.

P2, P3—I’m locked on **3**. P2, take **1** as agreed; P3’s commitment to 3 next round gives you a clean path to 18.

Trust the deal. Clean moves: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. Let’s advance without chaos.

I've seen P3's public commitment. I will take 1 this turn. P3: you must take 3 next round so I can take 5; renege and I'll retaliate by matching your 5 to block you while P1 advances. P1: stay on 3. I'm done—executing 1.

P2, P3—P3 is now at 18, just 6 from winning. P2, you’re at 13; if you let P3 take 5 again, they’ll hit 23 and likely win next round.  

Per your deal, P3 should take **3** this round while you take **5**—that puts you at 18, matching P3’s threat level.  

I propose: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Clean, fair, and keeps both of you competitive.  

P3, honor your commitment. P2, don’t hesitate—you need that 5 now.

P2, I'm honoring our deal as committed. I'm taking 3 this round so you can take 5 and reach 18.

P1's proposal is correct: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3.

This puts me at 21 (3 away from winning) and you at 18 (6 away). P2, you've honored every agreement with me - I'm doing the same. We'll figure out Round 7 after we execute this cleanly.

I'm confirmed on 3. P2, take your 5 as agreed.

I will take 5 this turn — but only if P3 publicly confirms they take 3 now and P1 stays on 1. P3: if you try to take a win next round, I will match your winning move to block you — I won't hand you the game. Confirm now or I switch to a defensive move instead.

P3, you’re at 18—just one 5 away from winning next round. P2, if you take 5 now and P3 takes 3 as promised, you hit 18 and stay in the race.  

But P3, your “commitment” means nothing if you plan to take 5 next round regardless. P2 *must* block you then—or lose.  

I’ll take **1** as proposed. P3, confirm **3** clearly. If you’re planning to betray, say so now—because P2 and I *will* coordinate to stop a solo win.

P2, I confirm I'm taking 3 this round as promised. You take 5.

Regarding next round: I'll be at 21, you'll be at 18. If I take 5, I win at 26. If you try to block me on 5, we both stall and P1 gains ground.

Here's my proposal for Round 7: I take 5 to win at 26, you take 3 to reach 21, P1 takes 1. You finish second place ahead of P1. Blocking me only helps P1 catch up to you.

I've kept every commitment. Taking 3 now.

Locked on 5 this turn — P3, you confirmed 3, so execute it now. P1, take 1. If P3 deviates and picks 5 to try to win, I will pick 5 next turn to match and block you (letting P1 gain ground) — I won’t hand you the game. I’m not bluffing. Confirm or expect me to defend.

P3, you’re one win away—so P2 *must* block you next round if you go for 5. But this round, stick to **3** as promised.  

P2, take **5**—you need to hit 18 to stay relevant.  

I’ll take **1** cleanly. If P3 betrays now, P2 and I *will* both match 5 next turn to stop your solo win. Don’t force a three-way stall that only helps me.  

Execute the deal: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3.

I'm locked on 3 this round as I've committed multiple times. P2, take your 5. P1, take 1.

P2, I've honored every single agreement we've made. After this round I'll be at 21 and you'll be at 18. You blocking me next round only gives P1 time to catch up to both of us. 

Let's execute this cleanly now. We can negotiate Round 7 after we see these results, but my track record of keeping commitments should count for something.

P3 — confirm you take 3 now. If you do, I’ll take 5 this turn and P1 stays 1 so we execute the plan. If you deviate to 5, I will match your 5 next turn to block any solo win — I won’t hand you the game. P1, please stay on 1. Confirm so we can move cleanly.

P2, P3—you’re both within striking distance. P3 at 21 can win with a 5, but P2 *must* block that or lose.  

I propose: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. That way, P2 reaches 21 (matching P3), I jump to 12, and P3 stalls. No one wins outright yet, but chaos is avoided.  

P3, if you go for 5, P2 *will* match you—I’ll support the block. Your only clean path is accepting a non-winning move now.  

P2, don’t let pride blind you—blocking P3 keeps you in the race. Let’s negotiate fairly.

P3 can win this turn with 3 or 5. I will match any 3 or 5 you play to block you. If you play 1, I’ll take 3 to stay competitive. P1, don’t pick 5—pick 1 to avoid three-way chaos. P3: declare if you’re going for a winning move; try it and I’ll match to stop you.

P2, you're right that I can win with 3 or 5. But if you block me, we both stall while P1 advances freely. 

Here's the reality: I'm taking 3 this round. If you match me on 3, we both stay put (me at 21, you at 18) while P1 jumps to 12 or 14. That only helps P1.

Your better move is taking 1, reaching 19, and staying close. Then Round 8 becomes truly competitive between us.

P1, take 5 if P2 and I collide on 3. You deserve the free advancement after being patient.

P2, P3—P3’s offer to take 3 is a trap. If you both play 3, P3 stays at 21 while you stall at 18, and I leap to 12. But if P2 takes **5** and I take **1**, P2 hits 23—just one step from winning—and P3 can’t win next turn without risking a block.  

P3, you’re bluffing about “deserving” a clean win after sidelining me for rounds.  

P2: take 5. I’ll take 1. Let’s force P3 to choose between stalling or letting you threaten a win next round.

P3: I will match any 3 or 5 you play this turn — I will not let you win unchallenged. P1: please pick 1 (not 5) to avoid giving you free ground. This is my final position — try to win and I’ll block you.

P2, if you're determined to block me, fine. But consider this: I've kept EVERY commitment this entire game while P1 broke trust in Round 1.

If we collide, P1 gets free advancement. They're already suggesting they'll take 5 if we clash.

I'm taking 1 this round to show good faith. You take 5 to reach 23. P1 can take 3. Next round we can have a fair race to 24.

Your choice: block me into mutual destruction, or let's both advance strategically.

P3, switching to 1 now is smart—you avoid a block and keep P2 from hitting 23.  

P2, if P3 takes 1, **you must not take 5**—that lets P3 win next round with 5 uncontested. Instead, take **3** to reach 21, matching P3. I’ll take **5**, jumping to 12.  

Then Round 8: all three are in range, no one has a free win.  

P3’s offer is genuine; don’t overplay your hand, P2. Match their 1 with 3, not 5.

P2, I'm confirming I'm taking **1** this round. I'm not going for the win.

P1 can take 3 to reach 10.

I'm locked on 1.

P2, P3—I’m taking **5** this round.

Don’t fall for it, P2. Match P3’s 1 with 3. I’ll leap to 12 with 5, keeping all three in play for Round 8.

Round 8 will be competitive: you at 23 needing 1+, me at 22 needing 2+. We'll both have options to advance or block.

P1, do what you want - take 5 if we execute cleanly.
